About

Hi there, I’m Ethan.

I’m a fourth-year undergraduate student at the University of Pittsburgh. I am a Bachelor of Philosophy candidate in the Department of Neuroscience, concentrating on computational biology and neuroinformatics. I’m also pursuing a Bachelor of the Arts in History and Philosophy of Science. In September 2017, I will be joining the Department of Biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to start a PhD in computational biology and genomics.

Past adventures have led me to the Gerstein Lab at Yale University, where I worked on peak calling methods for massively parallel regulatory assays and to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, where I worked with the McCombie Lab to improve NGS sequencing pipelines and develop in-silico simulation software for generation of PacBio long read data.

Some other current projects include development of computational models of neural circuits implicated in autonomic regulation with the Yates Lab at the University of Pittsburgh. Some past projects include a comparative transcriptomic analysis of the white pines with the Computational Genomics Laboratory at the University of Connecticut.

Outside of the lab, you can find me sailing, biking, hiking, or exploring Pittsburgh (probably by eating).

My CV is available here

Ethan Alexander García Baker | computational biologist
